Well, folks... I was suitably motivated to write it, at last: a 
Universal Parameterized Test Suite. This is a suite that allows you to 
implement the Parameterized Test Case without having to override 
runTest(). It therefore takes a collection of fixture objects, collects 
all the test methods in your TestCase class and build the default test 
suite with each fixture.

So if you have a TestCase with five tests and ten different fixtures, 
you get a suite with 50 tests. Get it?

There are some refactorings the JUnit sorely needs to improve the 
parameterized test suite's design -- most notably, TestSuite has too 
many responsiblities: it is both a test suite factory and the test suite 
itself. If we could extract the factory then ParameterizedTestSuite 
would be easier to implement and use.

How do you use it?

1. Add a constructor to your TestCase class to accept your fixture data 
from the outside. This replaces setUp().

2. Add the method setFixture() taking an instance of your TestCase as 
the parameter. Implement it to stash the parameter's fixture.

3. Override getName() so that you can report the fixture name /and/ the 
test name. (TestSuite's schizophrenic design makes this the lesser of 
two evil duplications.)

Now you create a ParameterizedTestSuite like so:

     public static Test suite() {
         return new ParameterizedTestSuite(
             Arrays.asList(
                 new Object[] {
                     new StringCompareToTest("Same length", "abc", 
"abd", "abe"),
                     new StringCompareToTest("Empty string", "", "abd", 
"abe"),
                     new StringCompareToTest("Different lengths", "abc", 
"abcd", "abcde"),
                     new StringCompareToTest("Spaces", "abc", "abc ", 
"abc  "),
                     new StringCompareToTest("Failing on purpose", 
"abc", "abf", "abe")}));
     }

These are String comparability tests, extending JUnit-addons' 
ComparabilityTestCase. Each fixture has a name, then its data. Notice 
that the last fixture is wrong: it expects "abf" to be less than "abe", 
but it is not. Here is the failure list.

Failing on 
purpose/testReturnValues(junit.cookbook.addons.test.StringCompareToTest)

Notice the fixture name is part of the test name. This is what you get 
for overriding getName().

I'm about to write this up (in JUnit Cookbook) and I will post the 
corresponding recipes (to the junit-cookbook group only) for review. I 
will be releasing ParameterizedTestSuite as part of Diasparsoft Toolkit 
1.0, whenever /that/ finally happens. :)
